M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, which is located in Bristol County.

Turner v. Jordan, 957 F.2d 815, 820 (1st.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of care to exercise reasonable supervision to ensure the safety of the children entrusted to its care, including Plaintiff’s minor son.
Turner v. Jordan, 957 F.2d 815, 820 (1st.case_name: C & W Leasing, Inc., Plaintiff-Counter-Defendant-Appellant v. Orix Credit Alliance, Inc., Defendant-Counterclaim
Turner v. Jordan, 957 F.2d 815, 820 (1st.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a commercial loan dispute between a corporate borrower and a lender, addressing issues of fraud, RICO, conversion, and related contract/equitable claims. It does not involve children, child care, or any duty to supervise minors, nor does it discuss a duty of care owed to protect children entrusted to a defendant’s care. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a duty of reasonable supervision for children in a custodial setting.
Turner v. Jordan, 957 F.2d 815, 820 (1st.relevant_excerpt: This removed diversity case involves a controversy between borrower and lender over three aspects of a loan. The borrower, C & W, alleged that Alliance, the lender, misrepresented the rate to be charged on the loan, miscalculated the amount of interest necessary to be paid upon prepayment, and inflated the amount necessary for prepayment by including an improper charge, and refused to pay to C & W the funds generated by the charge.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed a duty of care to exercise reasonable supervision to ensure the safety of the children entrusted to its care, including Plaintiff’s minor son.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent in Mullins v. Pine Manor College and focuses entirely on proximate cause, not on whether the defendant owed a duty of reasonable supervision to protect persons in its care. The majority opinion in Mullins does recognize such a duty by a college to its students, but the quoted dissent neither discusses children nor establishes the duty proposition claimed. Using this specific text to support a duty-of-care proposition is therefore inaccurate.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.

M.G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2.proposition: Defendant also had a specific duty to comply with its representations to parents that children in the after-school program would be "supervised at all times."

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to maintain adequate supervision of the children in the gymnasium, despite the foreseeable risk of harm posed by unsupervised children engaging in rough play.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s duty to supervise children in a gym and liability for foreseeable harm from unsupervised rough play. Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital involves a hospital’s alleged duty to control or detain a sedated adult patient to protect third-party motorists and a police officer; the SJC expressly holds that no such duty to third parties exists and also finds lack of proximate cause. The opinion does not address supervision of children, premises liability in a recreational setting, or any analogous duty, and thus does not support the claimed proposition.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “We have not previously recognized, and do not now recognize, a duty to a third person of a medical professional to control a patient (excluding a patient of a mental health professional…) arising from any claimed special relationship between the medical professional and the patient… The hospital owed no duty to Leavitt to control or detain the patient.”

Quinn v. Morganelli, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 5.raw_text: Quinn v. Morganelli, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 50, 53 (2008)
Quinn v. Morganelli, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 5.proposition: Defendant further breached its duty of care when its employee failed to address the specific reports of unsafe behavior, thereby allowing hazardous play to continue unchecked.
Quinn v. Morganelli, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 5.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s premises liability for a hazardous step and whether they breached a duty to maintain safe conditions and/or warn of a deceptive step-down. It does not involve employees, reported unsafe behavior, or a failure to intervene in ongoing hazardous play. Thus it does not support the specific proposition that a defendant breached its duty when an employee failed to address reports of unsafe behavior allowing hazardous play to continue.
Quinn v. Morganelli, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 5.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff contends that the premises were not in reasonably safe condition because the existence of the change in level between the hallway and the living room was obscured by the manner in which these areas were tiled and lit, and that the defendants breached their duty of care by failing to remedy this condition or to warn her about it.… Because in this case the hazard that resulted in the plaintiff’s injuries is not open and obvious as matter of law, the plaintiff is entitled to proceed on the theory that the defendants breached their common-law duty of care by failing to warn her of an unreasonable danger of which they were or should have been aware.”

Vintimilla v. O\u2019Brien, 68 Mass. App.raw_text: Vintimilla v. O’Brien, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1113 (2007)
Vintimilla v. O\u2019Brien, 68 Mass. App.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s son’s injuries, including but not limited to a concussion and associated medical treatment.

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant should have foreseen the substantial risk of harm from inadequate supervision, particularly given that the adult-to-child ratio was insufficient, and foreseeable complaints about roughhousing were ignored.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The case addresses foreseeability and inadequate securing/supervision of dangerous equipment (forklifts) in an area where intoxicated seamen and visitors are known to be present, not supervision of children or adult-to-child ratios, nor complaints about roughhousing. The holding is that the Authority should have foreseen unauthorized, dangerous operation of an unsecured forklift, making it negligent, but it does not discuss supervision ratios or ignored complaints. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about inadequate child supervision and ignored roughhousing complaints.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area…”

Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has incurred economic losses, including medical expenses and lost wages, as well as non-economic damages, including pain and suffering of Plaintiff’s minor son.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a homeowner/parent owed a duty to third parties allegedly injured by intoxicated minors at a party, and it affirms summary judgment for the defendant on the ground that no such duty existed. It does not address or recognize damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, or pain and suffering as a result of proven negligence; rather, it finds no actionable negligence by the defendant at all. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that, as a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred the specified economic and non-economic losses.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).relevant_excerpt: "We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available. The defendant’s conduct did not create a risk of injury to the plaintiff for which we are prepared to say the common law should provide a remedy."
